Award.AwardTitle: EFRI-ODISSEI: Synthesizing Ccomplex Structures from Programmable Self-Folding Active Materials
Award.AbstractNarration:
The research objective of this Emerging Frontiers in Research and Innovation (EFRI) Origami Design for the Integration of Self-assembling Systems for Engineering Innovation (ODISSEI) award is to discover new techniques for synthesizing complex 3D structures from programmable, self-folding 2D elements. Elements will be massively foldable, meaning fold characteristics and locations will be of near-infinite variety and not limited to pre-engineered folds or joints. This will be made possible by the incorporation of active shape memory layers that provide actuation capabilities. Elements will be programmed by specifying the locations and sequences of localized folding operations. Multiple elements will connect to form larger and more complex 3D structures. The research team will create new theories and methods for (a) multi-scale and multidisciplinary systems analysis and optimization; (b) active materials modeling and structural analyses; (c) computational folding algorithms for design synthesis; (d) geometric modeling, visualization, and fine art; and (e) bio-inspired folding-based design synthesis methods. Deliverables include simulation models of the self-folding material elements, experimental studies validating the simulation models, and a demonstration of the overall synthesis framework.

If successful, the results of this research will constitute a substantial leap forward in engineering technology and knowledge, allowing engineers to design complex systems in fundamentally new ways. The capability to program a material element to fold, un-fold, and re-fold in different ways will have a long-term impact on several areas of national need, including significant challenges in space missions, sustainability, and defense. Research results will be disseminated broadly. Graduate and undergraduate engineering students will benefit through classroom instruction and direct involvement in the research. Underrepresented students from the 6th-12th grade levels will learn about science, technology, engineering and mathematics (STEM) topics through a robotics competition organized in partnership with National Instruments. In partnership with the Center for Puppetry Arts in Atlanta, GA, the research team will produce origami-themed lessons about STEM subjects that will reach over 10,000 elementary-age school children annually.

This project is supported in part by funds from the Air Force Office of Scientific Research.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The research objective of this Emerging Frontiers in Research and Innovation (EFRI) Origami Design for the Integration of Self-assembling Systems for Engineering Innovation (ODISSEI) award was to discover and then later to implement new techniques for synthesizing complex 3D structures from self-folding 2D elements. The tools considered initially planar sheets with the potential for a near-infinite variety of fold locations and patterns, and in some cases were not limited to pre-engineered folds or joints due to the incorporation of active shape memory layers. The topics of fold scheduling and path planning were addressed such that structures were folded by specifying the locations and sequences of localized folding operations. 

Regarding intellectual merit, by the end of the project, the research team had created new theories and methods for (a) multi-scale and multidisciplinary systems analysis and optimization; (b) active materials modeling and structural analyses; (c) computational folding algorithms for design synthesis (Figure 1); (d) geometric modeling, visualization; and (e) bio-inspired folding-based design synthesis methods. All of these developments had been disseminated in dozens of conference presentations and archival journal papers. Further, a fully synthesized textbook on the topic of finite-strain folding in passive and active origami structures had been published (Figure 2), complete with work-out problems and shared implementation code.

Regarding broadening impacts, coordination and collaboration with Air Force Research Lab teams initiated very early, ensuring that the new design and analysis methods could be adopted in a more widespread manner. Dozens of graduate and undergraduate engineering students benefitted through direct involvement in the research, including those from underrepresented groups (e.g., several minority and female students). In partnership with the Center for Puppetry Arts in Atlanta, GA, the research team produced , marketed, and delivered origami-themed lessons about STEM subjects that will reached thousands of elementary-age school children annually (Figure 3). 

After completion of the original period of performance, a two-year funding supplement was requested and granted such that the collaborative efforts with the Air Force Research Lab could continue toward greater probability of eventual technology transition. The main objective of the supplement was to utilize the outcomes of modeling, design, and fabrication methodologies for the development of a broad spectrum of reconfigurable origami electromagnetic device applications consisting of complex origami folding kinematics, active material-based actuation, and tunable electromagnetic characteristics. An active reconfigurable origami reflector antenna was both modeled and prototyped (Figure 4) to assess the feasibility of the technology going forward and the maturity of the engineering and design tools used to create it. It was found that if a highly discretized parabola were to be used in addition to more actuating material, the antenna ideally could be morphed to broadcast its signal to any continuous shape (Figure 5).

FIGURES:

Figure 1: Illustration of the entire fold pattern design process for materials with smooth folds (e.g., being formed from active or passive material with strain limitations); curved tube shown in this example.

Figure 2: Cover of textbook published, which summarizes many of the developments funded in this effort. Text includes both work-out and guided design problems and is accompanied by all essential codes.

Figure 3: Advertising image for ?Folding Up,? an interactive distance education module developed and deployed by the Center for Puppetry Arts in Atlanta, which reached thousands of grade school students across the country and addressed multiple STEM topics including geometry and career selection.

Figure 4: The active reconfigurable origami reflector antenna prototype in position for testing. Both three dimensional digital image correlation and scanning with a laser displacement sensor were used to study the effect of actuation on the overall shape of the discretized parabola.

Figure 5: (a) and (b) show an ideally discretized parabola and a deformed discretized parabola, respectively, along with their associated radiation patterns projected onto the continental United States. Green in this case means that point is receiving sufficient signal, while red means a point is receiving an unsatisfactory amount of signal within a desired area and blue means a point outside a desired shape is receiving too strong of a signal.
